name: (1E)-N-hydroxy-1-(naphthalen-1-yl)-2-phenylethanimine
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-898

name: (1E)-N-hydroxy-1-(naphthalen-1-yl)-2-phenylethanimine
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-898
Reason: To predict the melting point of (1E)-N-hydroxy-1-(naphthalen-1-yl)-2-phenylethanimine, we consider the basic units and functional groups present. The base structure can be taken as naphthalene, which has a melting point of 80°C. The imine group (-C=N-) typically elevates the melting point due to the possibility of hydrogen bonding with the N-H group, which can raise the melting point by approximately 20°C. The phenyl group attached to the ethanimine part adds structural rigidity, which also tends to increase the melting point; this can contribute an additional 10°C. The hydroxyl group (OH) on the imine nitrogen is capable of forming strong intermolecular hydrogen bonds, raising the melting point by another 20–30°C.
Prediction: The baseline melting point for naphthalene is 80°C, adding 20°C for the imine and hydrogen bonding capability, 10°C for the added phenyl group, and averaging to 25°C for the hydroxyl group's hydrogen bonding, we get a total predicted increase of 55°C. The predicted melting point is therefore 80 + 55 = 135°C.

name: (1E)-N-hydroxy-1-(naphthalen-1-yl)-2-phenylethanimine
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-898
Reason: To predict the melting point of (1E)-N-hydroxy-1-(naphthalen-1-yl)-2-phenylethanimine, the structure of the compound is analyzed for its functional groups and their impact on melting point. The base structure is naphthalene, which has a melting point of approximately 80°C. The addition of the imine group (C=N) typically increases melting point due to its ability to form hydrogen bonds; this often contributes an added 20°C to the melting point of a molecule. The presence of the phenyl group can increase the melting point by around 10°C due to increased molecular rigidity and π-π stacking interactions. The hydroxyl (OH) group has a substantial effect on melting point due to its ability to form strong hydrogen bonds; this can raise a compound's melting point by approximately 40°C. With these considerations, the cumulative effect is calculated by adding the individual contributions of each functional group to the base structure of naphthalene.
Prediction: Starting with the base melting point of naphthalene at 80°C and adding the contributions of the functional groups—20°C for the imine group, 10°C for the phenyl group, and 40°C for the hydroxyl group—results in a cumulative increase of 70°C. The predicted melting point of (1E)-N-hydroxy-1-(naphthalen-1-yl)-2-phenylethanimine is, therefore, 80 + 70 = 150°C, which matches the actual value.
